entry.title: Books on Ida Lupino and her fascinating career
entry.summary: If you want to learn more about Ida Lupino and her fascinating life and career, here are the essential books: - *Ida Lupino: Beyond the Camera*, by Mary Ann Anderson with Ida Lupino, originally published 2011. 100th birthday special edition published 2018. > This is the closest thing we will...

div.p: If you want to learn more about Ida Lupino and her fascinating life and career, here are the essential books:

ul.li: Ida Lupino: Beyond the Camera, by Mary Ann Anderson with Ida Lupino, originally published 2011. 100th birthday special edition published 2018.

blockquote.p: This is the closest thing we will ever have to an Ida Lupino memoir. Alas it is thin on detail on Ida's life prior to 1983, and some of her early career detail appears chronologically inconsistent (likely relying on Ida's memory decades later). Yet this is a fascinating and crucial book for anyone who wants to get an understanding of Ida as a person. Mary Ann Anderson knew Ida better than anyone from 1983 until Ida's death in 1995.

ul.li: Ida Lupino: A Biography, by William Donati, originally published 1995.

blockquote.p: A wonderful and detailed biography, published shortly after Ida's death, by someone who clearly highly respected her, faults and all. If you read Anderson's book, you learn that Ida and Donati had a falling out. You would never know from reading Donati's book.

ul.li: Ida Lupino, Director: Her Art and Resilience in Times of Transition, by Therese Grisham, Julie Grossman, published 2017.

div.p: An academic-style book on Ida's directing career, both film and television.

ul.li: _Mr. Adams and Eve, Illustrated*, by Mary Ann Anderson, published 2010.

blockquote.p: More stories straight from the source, and lots of great pictures as well.

ul.li: The Making of the Hitch-Hiker, Illustrated, by Mary Ann Anderson, published 2013.

blockquote.p: More from Anderson, so always worthwhile.

div.p: Goodreads link: Ida Lupino: Beyond the Camera, by Mary Ann Anderson with Ida Lupino

p.em: originally posted in The Vintage Classics on October 30, 2018

div.p: Ida Lupino directed a large number of television shows on numerous programs between the late ‘50s and the late ‘60s, including shows such as The Twilight Zone, Have Gun Will Travel, The Fugitive, Thriller, and Alfred Hitchcock Presents.

This prolific TV directing career began in early 1956 with a half-hour episode of Screen Directors Playhouse. The show, titled No. 5 Checked Out, was based on a story Ida wrote. It starred Teresa Wright, William Talman, and Peter Lorre.
You can watch it at the link below.
YouTube link: Screen Directors Playhouse: No. 5 Checked Out

entry.title: Ida Lupino in a romantic comedy, "Pillow to Post" (1945)
entry.summary: *Pillow to Post* (1945). A rare and very fun Ida Lupino comedy film, where she plays a traveling saleslady posing as a military spouse in order to find a place to sleep in the wartime housing shortage. From the Donati bio of Ida: “Ida told [director] Vincent Sherman that Pillow...
entry.content:
Pillow to Post (1945). A rare and very fun Ida Lupino comedy film, where she plays a traveling saleslady posing as a military spouse in order to find a place to sleep in the wartime housing shortage.

From the Donati bio of Ida:

“Ida told [director] Vincent Sherman that Pillow to Post brought her more fan mail than any other film in her career. Servicemen wrote to her from around the world.”

Vincent Sherman, quoted in Mary Ann Anderson’s book:

“Soldiers just loved this film. Ida was delightful. There wasn’t any kind of part that she couldn’t have done, comedy or drama.”

originally posted in The Vintage Classics on October 30, 2018

entry.title: Ida Lupino's sitcom "Mr. Adams and Eve"
entry.summary: After her production company The Filmakers folded in 1954, Ida Lupino was invited by Dick Powell, David Niven, and Charles Boyer to join their regular television production, *Four Star Playhouse*. Her new television career eventually led to her starring in a hit sitcom called *Mr. Adams and Eve* for two...
entry.content:
After her production company The Filmakers folded in 1954, Ida Lupino was invited by Dick Powell, David Niven, and Charles Boyer to join their regular television production, Four Star Playhouse.

Her new television career eventually led to her starring in a hit sitcom called Mr. Adams and Eve for two years in 1957-58, receiving an Emmy nomination in the process. She starred with her current husband, Howard Duff, while her ex-husband and former partner at The Filmakers, Collier Young, was the producer.

Ida said: “We liked to think it was a sophisticated kind of comedy showing the behind the scenes antics of a couple of movie stars.”

Three episodes of the 66 filmed are on YouTube.

In one episode I haven’t found, Ida plays a dual role: her usual character, “Eve, the movie star”, and “Ida Lupino, the director” who was brought in to direct the fictional acting couple. I would love to be able to see that episode!

Photos: various shots of Ida Lupino and Howard Duff in Mr. Adams and Eve

originally published in The Vintage Classics on October 27, 2018

This is an excellent, tense thriller that deserves more attention. The lead role in the original hit play was played to great acclaim by...
entry.content:
After a tremendous run of successful roles at Warner Bros. in 1940-41, Ida Lupino starred in Ladies in Retirement (1941) for Columbia—-opposite her then-husband Louis Hayward. This is an excellent, tense thriller that deserves more attention.

The lead role in the original hit play was played to great acclaim by Flora Robson and meant for a woman of sixty. Director Charles Vidor imagined the film character to be forty. Ida was 23 and an eight-year veteran of motion pictures.

Columbia mogul Harry Cohn exclaimed to the producer, “You are out of your mind choosing this child to play that role.”

As William Donati writes in his bio of Lupino: “Ida's performance was one of her greatest. Her restraint as the cold-blooded Ellen made her all the more frightening.”

originally published in The Vintage Classics on October 27, 2018

entry.title: Article on Ida Lupino's "Outrage"
entry.summary: Here is an interesting article about *Outrage*, one of the most notable of the films directed by Ida Lupino. By Anne Morra of The Museum of Modern Art. Excerpt: “As a producer and director, Lupino ran her own show; she had a director’s chair on set with “Mother” emblazoned on...

div.p: Here is an interesting article about Outrage, one of the most notable of the films directed by Ida Lupino.
By Anne Morra of The Museum of Modern Art.

“As a producer and director, Lupino ran her own show; she had a director’s chair on set with “Mother” emblazoned on the back. This independence allowed her to take risks on narrative films that depicted real people in real situations, with messy lives, broken hearts, and darkened psyches. But with Lupino at the helm, these postwar American lives seemed unquestionably authentic.”
Article link: Ida Lupino's "Outrage", by Anne Morra

p.em: originally published in The Vintage Classics on October 25, 2018

entry.title: Ida Lupino on the demise of her independent production company, The Filmakers
entry.summary: Ida Lupino, in a 1967 essay: >Filmakers was doing fine but we made one fatal mistake. We were talked into the distribution business. I opposed them [her business partners, Collier Young and Malvin Wald] every step of the way. We were creative people; we were picture-making people, I argued. ‘We...

blockquote.p: Filmakers was doing fine but we made one fatal mistake. We were talked into the distribution business. I opposed them [her business partners, Collier Young and Malvin Wald] every step of the way. We were creative people; we were picture-making people, I argued. ‘We know nothing about distribution. Let’s stay away from it.’ I was outvoted, and pretty soon we were out of business.

entry.title: The films directed by Ida Lupino, 1949-1966
entry.summary: Films directed by Ida Lupino: - *Not Wanted* (1949), uncredited - *Never Fear* (1949), aka *The Young Lovers* - *Outrage* (1950) - *Hard, Fast and Beautiful* (1951) - *The Hitch-Hiker* (1953) - *The Bigamist* (1953) - *The Trouble with Angels* (1966) All but the last were with her production company,...
entry.content:
Films directed by Ida Lupino:

  • Not Wanted (1949), uncredited
  • Never Fear (1949), aka The Young Lovers
  • Outrage (1950)
  • Hard, Fast and Beautiful (1951)
  • The Hitch-Hiker (1953)
  • The Bigamist (1953)
  • The Trouble with Angels (1966)

All but the last were with her production company, The Filmakers---originally known as Emerald Productions.

In most of these she was additionally involved as writer, producer, or actor.

originally published in The Vintage Classics on October 25, 2018
